new_entries.title: Start your new repository with Copilot coding agent
new_entries.content: When creating a repository, you can now use Copilot coding agent to kickstart your work. On the “New repository” page, enter your prompt in the new Prompt field. After the repository is created, Copilot will open a draft pull request, write the requested code, and then request a review from you. This makes it easier than ever to get started on new projects. Copilot coding agent is available to Copilot Pro, Copilot Pro+, Copilot Business, and Copilot Enterprise subscribers. If you’re a Copilot Business or Copilot Enterprise subscriber, an administrator will have to enable Copilot coding agent from the “Policies” page before you can use it. To learn more, head over to our Copilot coding agent documentation. The post Start your new repository with Copilot coding agent appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

new_entries.title: Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 is in public preview for Copilot coding agent
new_entries.content: GitHub Copilot coding agent, our asynchronous developer agent, now works with Claude Sonnet 4.5, Anthropic’s most advanced model for coding and real-world agents. Claude Sonnet 4.5 is state of the art on the SWE-bench Verified evaluation, which measures real-world coding abilities. If you are a Copilot Pro or Copilot Pro+ user, coding agent will automatically use Claude Sonnet 4.5. If you are a Copilot Business or Copilot Enterprise user, an administrator will need to enable the Claude Sonnet 4.5 policy in Copilot settings. If this policy is not enabled, coding agent will continue to use Claude Sonnet 4. To learn more about Copilot coding agent, head to our documentation on coding agent. The post Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 is in public preview for Copilot coding agent appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

new_entries.title: Premium requests analytics page is now generally available
new_entries.content: Starting September 29, 2025, a new comprehensive premium request dashboard will be available that provides insights about your premium request activity dating back to August 1, 2025. This new dashboard aims to help enterprise customers, organizations, and individual developers easily understand how their usage translates to their final bill and provide answers to common premium request usage questions. The analytics page will be available as a subpage within the “Billing” platform pages. For more information, reference our billing documentation. Access to the analytics page follows the same pattern as the rest of the billing platform experience. It will be available to enterprise owners, organization owners, billing managers, and personal account users with Copilot subscriptions. We’re also shipping a dedicated API endpoint for premium request analytics data that allows users to build internal dashboards, create custom usage reports, and easily track expenses across teams. For more information reference our API documentation. Key features With the new analytics dashboard, you can: View total usage for premium requests across all products that consume premium requests. Track the count of premium requests consumed beyond your monthly quota. Monitor the total number of included premium requests consumed (i.e., requests used within your monthly quota). Filter usage by user, model, organization, and cost center. View detailed breakdowns by the number of included and billed premium requests. See associated gross and billed amounts for your premium request usage. The post Premium requests analytics page is now generally available appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

new_entries.title: GitHub Copilot in Visual Studio — September update
new_entries.content: The September 2025 update to Visual Studio brings game-changing Profiler and .NET Modernization agents, more powerful MCP interactions, and smarter code reviews. Highlights Here’s what’s new with GitHub Copilot in Visual Studio 2022 (v17.14): Profiler Agent: Get started with Profiler Agent to find and fix performance issues more easily than ever before. @Profiler in Copilot Chat provides AI-powered analysis to highlight bottlenecks, suggest fixes, and optimize benchmarks in a guided loop. .NET Modernization Agent: Upgrade your .NET projects to the latest versions and migrate them to Azure with the help of the .NET Modernization Agent. Right-click your project and select Modernize or prompt @Modernize directly in Copilot Chat to get started. Agent mode improvements: Use agent mode more seamlessly thanks to faster response times, cleaner file management, and greater control. Agent mode is faster, smoother, and more stable with updates every month. MCP prompts, resources, and sampling: Leverage more powerful and customizable model interactions with MCP prompts, contextual resources, and agentic sampling. Mermaid diagrams: Visualize data structures and workflows by generating Mermaid diagrams with Copilot and clicking Preview to see the rendered diagrams directly in your Markdown editor. Smarter code reviews: Access more powerful local code reviews with advanced reasoning, more insightful comments, and support for custom instructions. Download Visual Studio to experience all the new Copilot features today. To learn more about what’s new, check out the Visual Studio blog and release notes. What’s next for Copilot in Visual Studio Stay up to date on the latest Copilot features by following the Visual Studio blog, where you’ll find roadmap updates and opportunities to share feedback. For the latest news, release notes, videos, and community conversations, visit the Visual Studio Hub, your central resource for all things Visual Studio. The post GitHub Copilot in Visual Studio — September update appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

new_entries.title: Copilot coding agent remembers context within the same pull request
new_entries.content: Copilot coding agent is our asynchronous, background developer agent. Delegate a task to Copilot, and it opens a draft pull request, makes changes in the background, then requests review from you. After Copilot coding agent requests your review, you can leave comments, mentioning @copilot, to ask it to make changes. This starts a new session. Now, Copilot remembers context between sessions for the same pull request, instead of exploring the repository and reading the same files again and again. This makes the agent faster and more reliable for follow-up requests. Copilot coding agent is available to Copilot Pro, Copilot Pro+, Copilot Business, and Copilot Enterprise subscribers. If you’re a Copilot Business or Copilot Enterprise subscriber, an administrator will have to enable Copilot coding agent from the “Policies” page before you can use it. To learn more about Copilot coding agent, head to our documentation on coding agent. The post Copilot coding agent remembers context within the same pull request appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

new_entries.title: GitHub Spark in public preview for Copilot Enterprise subscribers
new_entries.content: Organizations often struggle to turn ideas into working software. Weeks go into specs or mocks that rarely make it to production, and even when they do, they often miss the mark. GitHub Spark changes that by enabling teams to focus on the what, not the how: validate ideas early with rapid prototypes, get concepts into production that might otherwise stall in the backlog, and collaborate around live applications instead of fragmented docs or mockups. Built directly into the GitHub platform that millions of developers already rely on, Spark offers a streamlined path from prototype to production. Repositories, Dependabot, Codespaces, and Copilot all work together out of the box, so teams can move faster without leaving the tools they trust. Developers, product managers, designers, and other team members can centralize collaboration around interactive prototypes, break down silos, and create internal tools that make everyday work more efficient. Key features Natural language to app: Describe your idea and watch Spark build it, with frontend and backend capabilities included. No setup required: Data, LLM inference, hosting, deployments, and GitHub auth all included out of the box. Add AI to your apps: Add intelligent features powered by LLMs from OpenAI, Meta, DeepSeek, xAI, and more—no API key management needed. One-click deployments: Publish your app with a single click, with various controls to make sharing secure for you and your team. Build your way: Use natural language, visual editing controls, or code with GitHub Copilot code completions at your fingertips to iterate on your ideas. Create a repository: Get a repository with your favorite functionality included in just a click. Everything stays synchronized so you aren’t trapped in a sandbox. Expand with Copilot agents: Open a codespace directly from Spark to iterate with Copilot agent mode or assign an issue to Copilot coding agent. Now available for Copilot Enterprise customers Spark is available today in public preview for all Copilot Enterprise customers. Spark messages use premium requests included in GitHub Copilot plans. How to enable Spark for your organization By default, Spark is disabled. Enterprise admins can enable Spark as follows: Navigate to your Enterprise Policies tab on github.com. Select Copilot in the left sidebar. Scroll down to the “Features” section where you will see “Spark”. Change the Spark policy setting to Enabled, which will enable Spark for all Copilot Enterprise users associated with your enterprise. Optionally, you can change the Spark policy setting at the enterprise level to No Policy and enable it at the organization level, which will enable Spark for only certain organizations within your enterprise. Once enabled, all Copilot subscribers associated with your enterprise or organization can access Spark at github.com/spark. Learn more View more details on the Spark product page. Read the Spark documentation. Join the discussion to share your feedback and ask questions. Disclaimer: The UI for features in public preview is subject to change. The post GitHub Spark in public preview for Copilot Enterprise subscribers appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

new_entries.title: Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 is in public preview for GitHub Copilot
new_entries.content: Claude Sonnet 4.5, Anthropic’s most advanced model for coding and real-world agents, is now rolling out in GitHub Copilot to Copilot Pro, Pro+, Business, and Enterprise. From our early testing, the model brings major upgrades in tool orchestration, context editing, and domain-specific capabilities. Availability in GitHub Copilot Copilot Chat Claude Sonnet 4.5 will be available for Copilot Pro, Pro+, Business, and Enterprise. You’ll be able to select the model in the Copilot Chat model picker from: Visual Studio Code in chat, ask, edit, and agent mode. github.com. GitHub Mobile in iOS and Android. Copilot CLI All users of Copilot Pro, Pro+, Business, and Enterprise will also be able to select Claude Sonnet 4.5 from the new model picker, available in the latest version of the Copilot CLI (v0.0.329). To switch to Claude Sonnet 4.5, update to the latest version with npm install -g @github/copilot, then use the /model command. Enabling access For all use cases, rollout will be gradual, check back soon if you don’t see it yet. Enterprise and Business plan administrators must enable the Claude Sonnet 4.5 policy in Copilot settings. Once enabled, users in that organization will have Claude Sonnet 4.5 available in the Copilot Chat model picker and Copilot CLI. Copilot Free, Pro, and Pro+ users may also bring their own key in Visual Studio Code by selecting Manage Models from the picker, choosing Anthropic, and entering their API key when prompted. Learn more To explore all models available in GitHub Copilot, see our documentation on models and get started with Copilot. Share your feedback Have feedback or questions? Join the community discussion to share your experiences and tips. The post Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 is in public preview for GitHub Copilot appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

new_entries.title: Kick off and track Copilot coding agent sessions from the GitHub CLI
new_entries.content: Copilot coding agent is our asynchronous, autonomous background agent. Delegate a task to Copilot, and it opens a draft pull request, makes changes in the background, then requests a review from you. The GitHub CLI 2.80.0 release introduces the agent-task command set for managing coding agent tasks in gh: Start a new task: gh agent-task create "refactor the codebase" List all your tasks: gh agent-task list View task details: gh agent-task view 1234 View the task log in real-time: gh agent-task view 1234 --log --follow The agent-task command set also ships with the following aliases for convenience: gh agent-tasks gh agent gh agents For more information about command line flags and arguments, run gh agent-task --help. The post Kick off and track Copilot coding agent sessions from the GitHub CLI appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

new_entries.title: Copilot can create issues with code snippets in public preview
new_entries.content: Following the release of using Copilot to create issues, we’re making issue creation even smarter. You can now ask Copilot to include relevant code snippets and files directly into your issues on github.com/copilot. You can now: Create an issue and ask Copilot to attach related code snippets or files. Add snippets after Copilot’s initial draft. Review and edit Copilot’s suggestions before creating the issue. Try it out Navigate to github.com/copilot. Try prompts like: “Create me an issue for YOUR-PROMPT-HERE in YOUR-ORGANIZATION/YOUR-REPOSITORY and add relevant code snippets.” Helpful tips Snippets aren’t added by default, so be sure to prompt Copilot to include them. Copilot may make mistakes, so always double-check the snippets and files it suggests. Be specific with your prompts to get the most useful results. With this update, issues can carry richer context from the start, helping you maintain continuity from reporting to implementation. The post Copilot can create issues with code snippets in public preview appeared first on The GitHub Blog.

new_entries.title: Upcoming deprecation of gh-copilot CLI extension
new_entries.content: We’re announcing the scheduled deprecation of the GitHub Copilot in the CLI extension for GitHub CLI (i.e., gh-copilot) which will stop working on October 25, 2025. This extension’s capabilities are being replaced by the new GitHub Copilot CLI, a fully agentic AI assistant that provides the full power of Copilot’s coding agent locally in your terminal. What’s changing The gh-copilot extension will be deprecated and stop functioning on October 25, 2025. Enterprise customers with the “Copilot in the CLI” policy currently enabled will notice we’re automatically disabling this policy. We’re doing this so administrators can review whether to allow access to the new Copilot CLI, which is now in public preview. The new Copilot CLI provides a much more powerful, agentic experience compared to the limited suggestion capabilities of gh-copilot. Migration and alternatives Copilot Pro and Enterprise users: We recommend migrating to the new GitHub Copilot CLI, which offers enhanced agentic capabilities. Free plan users: Since the new Copilot CLI isn’t available on the free plan, we recommend using Ask mode in Visual Studio Code to get explanations and command suggestions. Alternatively, you could explore the gh-models extension to interact with AI models via the GitHub CLI. For more information about the new GitHub Copilot CLI, visit the GitHub Copilot CLI repository. The post Upcoming deprecation of gh-copilot CLI extension appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
